translated: The Elder Akkantasaññaka
“In the past, I took a handful of grass🔽and offered it to my preceptor.
I was training in the recitation
in order to understand the faults of the texts.
I saw the dust-free Buddha,🔽the receiver of offerings,
the bull, the supreme one,🔽Tissa Buddha, best of assemblies.
The grass was spread out

analyzed: tissam buddham gaṇa uttama  kusāṭakam  akkamantam naruttama
translated: for the supreme human as he walked.
The great hero, who had risen up,
the best in the world, the bull among men.
Seeing that light of the world,
stainless like the moon,
I praised the Teacher’s feet
with a serene mind.
For ninety-four eons
I gave a handful of grass.
I do not recall any bad destination,
this is the fruit of the handful of grass.
Thirty-seven eons ago,
there was a lord of the people
named Sunanda,
a powerful wheel-turning monarch.
The four analytical knowledges …
… the Buddha’s instruction has been done.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā akkantasaññako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
